title: How to Adjust Intonation on Bass

steps.headline: Adjust your truss rod and adjust your action, if necessary, before setting the intonation of your bass.
steps.description:
Adjusting the truss rod and adjusting the action on your bass changes the distance between the bridge saddles and the nut. Any such change will affect the intonation of the bass. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/10\/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-1Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/10\/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-1Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Examine the bridge of your bass to determine the tool you will need to adjust the saddle positions.
steps.description: Obtain the necessary tool, which can be a small flat-blade screwdriver, small Phillips screwdriver or an allen wrench.

steps.headline: Plug your bass into an electronic tuner.
Tune each string on your bass.
Play the harmonic of the G-string at the 12th fret.
Fret the G-string at the 12th fret and play the note.
Adjust the bridge saddle to correct the bass string intonation.
Repeat the process.
Repeat the process for each of the other strings.

tyn: Small flat blade screwdriver, small Phillips screwdriver or allen wrench
text:
Adjust your truss rod and adjust your action, if necessary, before setting the intonation of your bass. Adjusting the truss rod and adjusting the action on your bass changes the distance between the bridge saddles and the nut. Any such change will affect the intonation of the bass. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/10/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-1Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/10/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-1Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Examine the bridge of your bass to determine the tool you will need to adjust the saddle positions. Obtain the necessary tool, which can be a small flat-blade screwdriver, small Phillips screwdriver or an allen wrench. Plug your bass into an electronic tuner. Tune each string on your bass. Recheck and adjust the tuning of each string after tuning all of the strings. Changing the tension on each string will affect the tuning of the other strings. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a9/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-4Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a9/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-4Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Continue tuning each of the strings until they are all in tune simultaneously. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/77/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-4Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/77/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-4Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Play the harmonic of the G-string at the 12th fret. Lightly touch your finger on the string directly over the 12th fret. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/59/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-5Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/59/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-5Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Verify on the tuner that the string is tuned exactly to G.{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f0/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-5Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-5Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f0/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-5Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-5Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Fret the G-string at the 12th fret and play the note. Fret the string directly behind the fret. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-6Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-6Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-6Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-6Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Fret the string with the same pressure that you would ordinarily use while playing. Resist the temptation to press more firmly on the string. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-6Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-6Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-6Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-6Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Note the tuning on the electronic tuner. If this note is sharp (above the tone of the harmonic), then the string length from the nut to the bridge needs to be increased. If the fretted note is flat (below the tone of the harmonic), then the string length from the nut to the bridge needs to be decreased. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/76/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-6Bullet3.jpg/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-6Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/76/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-6Bullet3.jpg/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-6Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Adjust the bridge saddle to correct the bass string intonation. If the string length needs to be increased, turn the bridge saddle adjustment screw clockwise. If the string length needs to be decreased, turn the bridge saddle adjustment screw counterclockwise. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bb/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-7Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bb/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-7Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Determine how much to change the saddle adjustment based on how far out of tune the fretted note was. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5e/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-7Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-7Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5e/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-7Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-7Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Repeat the process. Play the harmonic to verify that the string is still in tune after adjusting the bridge saddle location. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/90/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-8Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/90/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-8Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Fret the string at the 12th fret and play the note. Observe whether this note is in tune, sharp or flat. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/38/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-8Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-8Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/38/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-8Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-8Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Repeat the process until the note played with the string fingered at the 12th fret is the same and in tune with the harmonic played at the 12th fret. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f0/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-5Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-5Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f0/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-5Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-5Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Repeat the process for each of the other strings.
sentences: Adjust your truss rod and adjust your action, if necessary, before setting the intonation of your bass.
Adjusting the truss rod and adjusting the action on your bass changes the distance between the bridge saddles and the nut.
Any such change will affect the intonation of the bass.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/10\/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-1Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/10\/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-1Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Examine the bridge of your bass to determine the tool you will need to adjust the saddle positions.
Obtain the necessary tool, which can be a small flat-blade screwdriver, small Phillips screwdriver or an allen wrench.
Plug your bass into an electronic tuner.
Tune each string on your bass.
Recheck and adjust the tuning of each string after tuning all of the strings.
Changing the tension on each string will affect the tuning of the other strings.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a9\/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a9\/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Continue tuning each of the strings until they are all in tune simultaneously.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/77\/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-4Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/77\/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-4Bullet2.jpg\/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Play the harmonic of the G-string at the 12th fret.
Lightly touch your finger on the string directly over the 12th fret.

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/59/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-5Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/59/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-5Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Verify on the tuner that the string is tuned exactly to G.{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f0/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-5Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-5Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f0/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-5Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-5Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Fret the G-string at the 12th fret and play the note.
Fret the string directly behind the fret.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/0b\/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-6Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-6Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/0b\/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-6Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-6Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Fret the string with the same pressure that you would ordinarily use while playing.
Resist the temptation to press more firmly on the string.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/9d\/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-6Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-6Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/9d\/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-6Bullet2.jpg\/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-6Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Note the tuning on the electronic tuner.
If this note is sharp (above the tone of the harmonic), then the string length from the nut to the bridge needs to be increased.
If the fretted note is flat (below the tone of the harmonic), then the string length from the nut to the bridge needs to be decreased.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/76\/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-6Bullet3.jpg\/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-6Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/76\/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-6Bullet3.jpg\/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-6Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Adjust the bridge saddle to correct the bass string intonation.
If the string length needs to be increased, turn the bridge saddle adjustment screw clockwise.
If the string length needs to be decreased, turn the bridge saddle adjustment screw counterclockwise.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/bb\/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-7Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/bb\/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-7Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Determine how much to change the saddle adjustment based on how far out of tune the fretted note was.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/5e\/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-7Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-7Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/5e\/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-7Bullet2.jpg\/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-7Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Repeat the process.
Play the harmonic to verify that the string is still in tune after adjusting the bridge saddle location.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/90\/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-8Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/90\/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-8Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Fret the string at the 12th fret and play the note.
Observe whether this note is in tune, sharp or flat.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/38\/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-8Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-8Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/38\/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-8Bullet2.jpg\/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-8Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Repeat the process until the note played with the string fingered at the 12th fret is the same and in tune with the harmonic played at the 12th fret.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f0\/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-5Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-5Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f0\/Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-5Bullet2.jpg\/v4-760px-Adjust-Intonation-on-Bass-Step-5Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Repeat the process for each of the other strings.
